remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I understand you've been experiencing significant shortness of breath and headaches. Can you tell me more about how your symptoms of dyspnea have changed since they began?

Um, yes, thank you, doctor. Well, the main thing is I’ve just been really short of breath—like, much more than usual for me. It’s gotten worse over the last couple days. And, um, I’ve also noticed these mildly painful little pimples on the sides of my tongue. I’m feeling pretty anxious about all this.

remedi_labels.value: mildly painful pimples on the sides of tongue

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—experiencing worsening shortness of breath and new symptoms like tongue lesions can be very concerning. Since your shortness of breath worsens with minimal exertion and is accompanied by dizziness, have you noticed any chest pain, palpitations, or swelling in your legs during these episodes?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially given your medical history and the severity of your symptoms. And, actually, I’m really concerned about the hypoxia—I’ve been needing more oxygen than usual, and when I try to walk, my oxygen saturation drops into the 60s or 70s. That’s never happened before.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with your history of interstitial lung disease and immunosuppression, combined with worsening dyspnea, hypoxia, fever, headache, and clinical examination aches. To further guide my assessment, have you noticed any new cough, sputum production, or changes in the color of your sputum recently?

Well, um, actually, I haven’t really had much of a cough, and I’m not bringing up any sputum—there’s no change in color or anything like that. It’s mostly just this really bad shortness of breath and, like I mentioned, the hypoxia. I’ve noticed my oxygen requirements have gone up a lot—I need more oxygen than usual just to keep my saturation up, and when I try to walk even a few steps, my oxygen saturation drops into the 60s or 70s. That’s never happened before, and it’s honestly making me really anxious.

With all these symptoms—especially the fever, headpain, body pains, and the increasing oxygen requirements—should I be worried about something infectious? Or could this be a flare of my interstitial lung disease? I just want to know what to expect or what the next steps might be.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with your history of interstitial lung disease, immunosuppression, and these worsening symptoms. Based on your description—worsening dyspnea, hypoxia with minimal exertion, fever, headache, and clinical examination aches—my assessment is that both a respiratory infection (such as pneumonia) and a flare of your underlying lung condition are possible, and both can be serious in your context.

To clarify the cause, we will need to perform a thorough clinical evaluation, including a physical examination, chest imaging (such as a chest X-ray or CT scan), and laboratory diagnostic evaluations to assess for infection or inflammation. We may also obtain sputum cultures and blood work to look for infectious organisms. In the meantime, it’s important to continue supplemental oxygen and monitor your oxygen saturation closely.

Have you noticed any new rashes or skin changes since your symptoms began? This can sometimes help us narrow down the cause of your current condition.

remedi_labels.value: worsening dyspnea, hypoxia with minimal exertion, fever, headache, clinical examination aches
respiratory infection (such as pneumonia), flare of underlying lung condition
thorough clinical evaluation, physical examination, chest imaging (chest X-ray or CT scan), laboratory diagnostic evaluations, sputum cultures, blood work
continue supplemental oxygen and monitor oxygen saturation closely
